metadata.title: Why Antiparticles Must Exist in Nature | by Marco Tavora Ph.D. | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Why Antiparticles Must Exist in Nature
metadata.description: In the following, I will argue (following Feynman) that two conditions are needed for antiparticles to exist in Nature: the first is that the energy of a particle is always positive, and the second…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: energy of a particle is always positive

all_paragraphs: In the following, I will argue (following Feynman) that two conditions are needed for antiparticles to exist in Nature: the first is that the energy of a particle is always positive, and the second is that Nature obeys the principles of relativity.

In order to fully grasp the conclusion of this article, an explanation of the geometric properties of spacetime diagrams (or Minkowski diagram) is needed. Spacetime diagrams are graphical representations of the motion of particles in spacetime.

To better understand the possible types of intervals in a spacetime diagram, it is better to use only two dimensions, one time dimension (vertical axis) and one spatial dimension (horizontal axis), as shown in Figure 2. The trajectory of an observer on a diagram is called a world line.

In a Minkowski diagram, the velocity is the reciprocal of the slope of a curve. A photon moves in the speed of light v=c, and a 45 degrees line describes it (we choose c=1 for convenience). An observer moving at a constant intermediate speed between zero (a vertical line represents a particle at rest) and the speed of light, moves in a line with an intermediate slope. Other types of world lines cannot have slopes smaller than 1, which restricts them to the region in Fig.2 bounded by the two 45 degrees lines (which form a wedge). An observer cannot enter the region outside the wedge. If there were two events in this outer region influencing each other, a message between them would be faster than light, and causality would be violated since the order of the events would change depending on the reference frame. This will be discussed in more detail later on.

Every type of particle in Nature has its associated antiparticle. Antiparticles have the same mass as its associated particle but opposite charge. The most famous example is the positively charged positron (or antielectron). The positron is the antiparticle associated with the negatively charged electron. Most standard quantum field theory books define antiparticles in the same way. Here I will follow Lancaster and Blundell’s approach, which is quite refreshing.

In the 1940s, Richard Feynman and Ernst Stuckelberg (independently) introduced the idea of treating states with negative energy as particles moving backward in time. We now call these states antiparticles. For example, if in the equation of motion (EOM) for a charged particle in an electromagnetic field

one changes the sign of the time one immediately sees it has the same effect as inverting charge. These imply that a particle moving backward in time looks precisely like an antiparticle with the opposite charge moving forward in time.

Let me briefly mention the so-called CPT theorem, a fundamental symmetry obeyed by all physical phenomena. CPT stands respectively for charge C, parity P, and time-reversal T. According to this theorem, under charge conjugation, parity transformation, and time-reversal, the physical laws are unchanged. In our present case, we can ignore P and focus on CT. Another way to interpret an antiparticle is to state that it is CT-symmetric.
Let us consider a particle in some initial state ψᵢ. In quantum mechanics, the transition amplitude and the probability for the particle to make the transition
where K is referred to as the propagator. The Green’s function corresponding to the propagator reads:
Note that causality is built into the Green’s function by the Θ function, which is zero if its argument is negative (if the final time is greater than the initial time).
If the system is time translationally invariant, the propagator only depends on the time difference t − t′. The free Green’s function G₀ is given by:
The figure above describes the following returning transition:

The scattering of one particle on another particle is described by the interaction with a potential V(x,t). In the presence of interactions, the transition amplitude or the Green’s function cannot be calculated exactly. One then uses a perturbation expansion (valid for small a potential V):
Now, the function Green’s function G₀ can be expressed as an integral in momentum space:

Now suppose the particle interacts twice with a potential V(x,t), at points x₁ and x₂. Let us, for simplicity, denote the coordinate pair (x,t) by x. To find the amplitude for the initial state ψᵢ to return to ψᵢ after two interactions, let us follow Feynman and write the three steps followed by the particle, namely:
Eq. 9 can be written taking the intermediate states to be plane waves (note that some constants were omitted):
The factors a and b read:
where the energy is given in Eq. 8. Hence the intermediate states are particles with momentum p and energy E(p) (see Feynman). The figure below illustrates the process:

Since we are interested in the probability that the particle returns to its initial state (up to second order in the potential V) we sum the amplitudes of direct transition (without any Vs) given by Eq. 6 with the one corresponding to the V² scattering given by Eq. 10 and square the result. The probability (up to V²) becomes:

The Fourier transform of a function f(τ) is equal to its decomposition into constituent frequencies ω (note that Fourier transforms are not limited to the variables t and ω only). The Fourier transform outputs a complex function of ω. Its modulus expresses the amount of each frequency in the original function f(τ). The inverse Fourier transform synthesizes the original function f(τ) from its frequency domain representation (see Wikipedia). Mathematically the Fourier transform and its inverse are given by:
The figure below illustrates a Fourier transform from time to frequency.
To prove the inevitability of antiparticles we suppose that all energies are positive (see Feynman). We then transform the momentum integral in Eq. 12 given by:
into an integral over the energy ω=E(p) and define a function F(ω) such that F(ω)=0 for ω < m. Note that the x₁, x₂ dependence is contained in F(ω).

Following Feynman, consider the following theorem. If function f(t) can be decomposed into positive frequencies only (as in Eq. 15), according to this theorem, f(t) cannot be zero for any finite range of time t=t₂- t₁ unless it vanishes identically for all times.
Let us now apply this theorem to our present case. First, fix the space coordinates x₁ and x₂ and consider the ω-dependent version of the momentum integral.

But for a fixed x₁, the momentum integral Eq. 14 cannot be equal to zero when the second coordinate x₂ lies outside the lightcone of x₁. We conclude that Eq. 14 must include nonzero amplitudes containing spacelike intervals (particles moving faster than light).

But as we explained in the introduction, spacelike intervals have frame-dependent order of events. Hence some of the intermediate particles are seen in another reference frame as particles “propagating back in time.” (see Fig. 11). Now, to conclude the discussion, let us add an electric charge to the particle. As explained above, according to the Feynman–Stueckelberg's interpretation, these intermediate (or virtual) particles that are moving backward in time are equivalent to antiparticles moving forward in time!

To make the argument clearer let us examine Fig. 11 in detail. Suppose we change into a new (primed) reference frame where t₂< t₁. Let us see what happens. In the new reference frame, until t=t₂ there is just one moving particle ψᵢ. However, at t₂ the potential V creates two particles, and one of them seems to be moving backward in time. Then at t₁ the original particle and the backward moving particle meet and vanish. In other words, the two particles annihilate each other in the new reference frame.
We conclude therefore that the two conditions (energy positivity and relativity) imply that pairs of particles can be created and annihilated!
